The History of Mexican Immigrants in the United States

Creator: Delano, Jack,

Title: Topeka, Kansas. Two Mexican workers employed at the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad locomotive shops

Date: 1943 March

Format: Photograph

Institution: Farm Security Administration - Office of War Information photograph collection (Library of Congress)

Link: https://www.loc.gov/resource/fsa.8d15012/

Mexicans have a rich history with the United States and are among one of the oldest groups of people to live in the United States. Mexicans are the largest ethnic group of Spanish speaking descent that make up the United States and they also make up most of the people living in the United States. When Mexicans began migrating to the United States, many of them typically found themselves working in the farming and ranching industry. When the railroad industry was booming, this industry also gave Mexicans an opportunity to find work at a low-cost wage. While working in the railroad industry, many Mexicans viewed the railroad industry as an opportunity to move their families to different parts of the United States. Many moved to the urban cities in the North and East of the United States. During World War 2, the United States created the Bracero Program, a program that brought over Mexican Laborers to help the shortage of American workers that went off to war.
